articles.headline: Investors Who Put $2 Billion Into FTX Face Scrutiny, Too
articles.snippet: Venture capital firms and investment funds showered the failed crypto exchange and its founder with money. There were few strings attached.
articles.abstract: Venture capital firms and investment funds showered the failed crypto exchange and its founder with money. There were few strings attached.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried’s pitch to investors was not much of a pitch: It was a take-it-or-leave-it offer.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: A Verifiable Mess: Twitter Users Create Havoc by Impersonating Brands
articles.snippet: The social media service, which is undergoing changes from its new owner Elon Musk, has descended into a messy swirl of spoof messages and parody accounts.
articles.abstract: The social media service, which is undergoing changes from its new owner Elon Musk, has descended into a messy swirl of spoof messages and parody accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The parody accounts were proliferating on Twitter.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Benjamin Mullin, Kate Conger and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Ukrainian Forces Enter Kherson, a Strategic Prize, in a Blow to Putin
articles.snippet: Jubilant crowds poured into the streets, greeting Ukrainian soldiers and waving flags. But officials said the city was not out of danger, warning of potential Russian reprisals.
articles.abstract: Jubilant crowds poured into the streets, greeting Ukrainian soldiers and waving flags. But officials said the city was not out of danger, warning of potential Russian reprisals.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLAHODATNE, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers swept into the southern city of Kherson on Friday, seizing a major symbolic and strategic prize from the retreating Russian army and dealing a bitter blow to President Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Ukrainian Soldiers Sweeping Into Kherson Are Greeted With Jubilation
articles.snippet: After months of Russian occupation, residents said the moment recalled being liberated from the Nazis in World War II. But there was also fear about further Russian attacks.
articles.abstract: After months of Russian occupation, residents said the moment recalled being liberated from the Nazis in World War II. But there was also fear about further Russian attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian soldiers arrived like heroes, greeted with kisses and songs. In the city of Kherson, which had endured months of Russian occupation, residents poured into the streets on Friday. They hoisted Ukrainian flags, and danced in joy around a glowing bonfire.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Anna Lukinova and Maria Varenikova

articles.headline: Mark Kelly Wins Arizona Senate Race, Putting Democrats a Seat From Control
articles.snippet: Mr. Kelly, who ran as a bipartisan legislator devoted to the needs of Arizona, defeated Blake Masters, a Republican newcomer whose ideological fervor failed to win over enough independent voters.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kelly, who ran as a bipartisan legislator devoted to the needs of Arizona, defeated Blake Masters, a Republican newcomer whose ideological fervor failed to win over enough independent voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona won a tough campaign for re-election on Friday, The Associated Press reported, defeating his Trump-backed Republican rival, Blake Masters, to put Democrats within one seat of retaining control of the Senate.

articles.headline: Ukraine Signals It Will Stay on the Offensive, Despite Talk of a Lull
articles.snippet: Many analysts and diplomats have suggested there could be a pause in major combat, and even peace talks, over the winter, but after pushing the Russians out of Kherson, Ukraine has no desire to stop.
articles.abstract: Many analysts and diplomats have suggested there could be a pause in major combat, and even peace talks, over the winter, but after pushing the Russians out of Kherson, Ukraine has no desire to stop.
articles.lead_paragraph: As jubilant Ukrainian troops hoist their national flag over Kherson after a comprehensive Russian retreat, they give no sign of stopping their offensives for the winter, or allowing the war to settle into a stalemate.

articles.headline: Kittens? Sex Toys? Pushing the Limits of Flexible Spending Accounts.
articles.snippet: The deadline for spending the money in the health accounts is approaching, and people are stretching the definition of eligible expenses.
articles.abstract: The deadline for spending the money in the health accounts is approaching, and people are stretching the definition of eligible expenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I walked by a local optometrist’s office, and there in the window was a come-on to tax nerds and people who needed to get thisclose to see the sign in the first place. “We accept FLEX SPENDING for FUTURE CREDIT.”

articles.headline: Trump Angst Grips Republicans (Again) as 2024 Announcement Looms
articles.snippet: While Republicans pick up the pieces from the midterm elections, former President Donald J. Trump is already forcing them to take sides in the next election.
articles.abstract: While Republicans pick up the pieces from the midterm elections, former President Donald J. Trump is already forcing them to take sides in the next election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the votes are even fully counted in the 2022 midterm election, Republicans are starting to face a decision: Do they stick with Donald J. Trump into 2024 or leave him behind?
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Internal Documents Show How Close the F.B.I. Came to Deploying Spyware
articles.snippet: Christopher Wray, the F.B.I.’s director, told Congress last December that the bureau purchased the phone hacking tool Pegasus for research and development purposes.
articles.abstract: Christopher Wray, the F.B.I.’s director, told Congress last December that the bureau purchased the phone hacking tool Pegasus for research and development purposes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During a closed-door session with lawmakers last December, Christopher A. Wray, the director of the F.B.I., was asked whether the bureau had ever purchased and used Pegasus, the hacking tool that penetrates mobile phones and extracts their contents.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: In an Era of Confrontation, Biden and Xi Seek to Set Terms
articles.snippet: Their first in-person presidential meeting, coming after both warned of deepening military, economic and diplomatic rivalry, will show how they address a range of U.S.-China tensions.
articles.abstract: Their first in-person presidential meeting, coming after both warned of deepening military, economic and diplomatic rivalry, will show how they address a range of U.S.-China tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just weeks after President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, laid out competing visions of how the United States and China are vying for military, technological and political pre-eminence, their first face-to-face meeting as top leaders will test whether they can halt a downward spiral that has taken relations to the lowest level since President Nixon began the opening to Beijing half a century ago.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: U.K. Doubles Down on a Tactic Disproportionately Targeting Black People
articles.snippet: The United States helped inspire Britain’s tough-on-crime politics. Even as crime fell and warnings mounted, politicians never looked back.
articles.abstract: The United States helped inspire Britain’s tough-on-crime politics. Even as crime fell and warnings mounted, politicians never looked back.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — The United Kingdom’s highest court delivered what seemed like a major victory for civil liberties in 2016, ruling that prosecutors had overreached for decades in using a tactic that sent hundreds of people to prison for life — for murders committed by others.

articles.headline: How the 2022 Midterms Became a Squeaker
articles.snippet: Interviews with more than 70 current and former officials show the outside forces — and miscalculations and infighting — that led to an improbable, still-undecided election.
articles.abstract: Interviews with more than 70 current and former officials show the outside forces — and miscalculations and infighting — that led to an improbable, still-undecided election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late one mid-September evening, the leaders of the House Democratic campaign arm were in the middle of a marathon meeting, grappling with an increasingly hostile midterm landscape. Two choices were on the table: a more defensive posture to limit their losses in the face of a potential red wave or a more aggressive approach in hopes of saving their paper-thin majority.

articles.headline: The Bike Thieves of Burlington, Vermont
articles.snippet: A hunt for stolen goods has put citizens and business owners in the center of a debate about policing and a growing, sometimes violent, problem with crime.
articles.abstract: A hunt for stolen goods has put citizens and business owners in the center of a debate about policing and a growing, sometimes violent, problem with crime.
articles.lead_paragraph: Burlington, Vt., is a bike-friendly city. There are multiple bike stores, a network of bright green bike lanes on many major streets and a waterfront bike path with views of the dazzling sunsets over Lake Champlain and the Adirondack Mountains.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Andres Kudacki

articles.headline: Democrats Hold the Senate, as Cortez Masto Ekes Out a Victory in Nevada
articles.snippet: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto defeated Adam Laxalt, the state’s former attorney general. Democrats now will try to add to their control of the chamber in Georgia’s runoff election on Dec. 6.
articles.abstract: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto defeated Adam Laxalt, the state’s former attorney general. Democrats now will try to add to their control of the chamber in Georgia’s runoff election on Dec. 6.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats sealed control of the Senate on Saturday as Senator Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada narrowly defeated Adam Laxalt, a Republican former state attorney general, a decisive moment in an extraordinary midterm election in which Democrats defied historical patterns and predictions of major losses.

articles.headline: Electric Vehicles Start to Enter the Car-Buying Mainstream
articles.snippet: While sales are still skewed toward affluent buyers, more people are choosing electric vehicles to save money.
articles.abstract: While sales are still skewed toward affluent buyers, more people are choosing electric vehicles to save money.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first wave of people who bought electric cars tended to be affluent, environmentally aware technology enthusiasts who lived in California. The second wave may be people like Russell Grooms, a librarian in Virginia.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Democrats’ Senate Victory Hands Biden a Critical Guardrail Against the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Even a bare-minimum majority preserves Democrats’ ability to confirm President Biden’s nominees and would allow them to stop Republican legislation in its tracks should the G.O.P. win the House.
articles.abstract: Even a bare-minimum majority preserves Democrats’ ability to confirm President Biden’s nominees and would allow them to stop Republican legislation in its tracks should the G.O.P. win the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after clinching a narrow hold on the Senate, Democrats began laying plans on Sunday to use their majority as a bulwark for President Biden in Congress should Republicans wrest control of the House, including by confirming his nominees, killing G.O.P. legislation on arrival and promoting their own policies to voters.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Russia Tried to Absorb a Ukrainian City. It Didn’t Work.
articles.snippet: In Kherson, national songs were banned, speaking Ukrainian could lead to arrest, and students were told they were Russian. Cue the resistance.
articles.abstract: In Kherson, national songs were banned, speaking Ukrainian could lead to arrest, and students were told they were Russian. Cue the resistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHERSON, Ukraine — Iryna Dyagileva’s daughter attended a school where the curriculum included memorizing the Russian national anthem. But teachers ignored it, instead quietly greeting students in the morning with a salute: “Glory to Ukraine!”

articles.headline: An Emboldened Biden Now Faces a Tough Choice About His Own Future
articles.snippet: The president feels buoyant after the better-than-expected midterms. But as he nears his 80th birthday, he confronts a decision on whether to run in 2024 that has some Democrats uncomfortable.
articles.abstract: The president feels buoyant after the better-than-expected midterms. But as he nears his 80th birthday, he confronts a decision on whether to run in 2024 that has some Democrats uncomfortable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — These are heady days for President Biden. The midterm elections offered long-sought validation. Democrats held onto the Senate, and even if they lose the House it will be by a narrow margin. The Republicans are in retreat and, by the way, so are the Russians and, just a bit at least, so is inflation.

articles.headline: FTX’s Collapse Casts a Pall on a Philanthropy Movement
articles.snippet: Sam Bankman-Fried, the chief executive of the embattled cryptocurrency exchange, was a proponent and donor of the “effective altruism” movement.
articles.abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried, the chief executive of the embattled cryptocurrency exchange, was a proponent and donor of the “effective altruism” movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: In short order, the extraordinary collapse of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX has vaporized billions of dollars of customer deposits, prompted investigations by law enforcement and destroyed the fortune and reputation of the company’s founder and chief executive, Sam Bankman-Fried.

articles.headline: Trump Wanted I.R.S. Investigations of Foes, Top Aide Says
articles.snippet: John F. Kelly, who was White House chief of staff, said that as president, Donald J. Trump wanted investigations into perceived enemies like James Comey, the former F.B.I. director.
articles.abstract: John F. Kelly, who was White House chief of staff, said that as president, Donald J. Trump wanted investigations into perceived enemies like James Comey, the former F.B.I. director.
articles.lead_paragraph: While in office, President Donald J. Trump repeatedly told John F. Kelly, his second White House chief of staff, that he wanted a number of his perceived political enemies to be investigated by the Internal Revenue Service, Mr. Kelly said.

articles.headline: TikTok Builds Itself Into an Ads Juggernaut
articles.snippet: The Chinese-owned video app’s ad business is thriving, even as a digital advertising slump hurts Meta, Snap and other rivals.
articles.abstract: The Chinese-owned video app’s ad business is thriving, even as a digital advertising slump hurts Meta, Snap and other rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Tiffany & Company shared a sleek black-and-white video featuring the pop superstar Beyoncé dripping in gems and surrounded by nightclub revelers. The minute-long jewelry ad was posted on Instagram, where it drew 1.6 million views.
articles.byline: By Kalley Huang, Isabella Simonetti and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: What One Importer’s Legal Fight Says About the Power of Cargo Giants
articles.snippet: The Biden administration has vowed to crack down on abuses by ocean carriers. But cases at the Federal Maritime Commission reveal the challenges of the campaign.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration has vowed to crack down on abuses by ocean carriers. But cases at the Federal Maritime Commission reveal the challenges of the campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like the rest of the e-commerce world, Jacob Weiss was contending with excruciating difficulties in getting his goods — mostly furniture — across the Pacific from factories in China.

articles.headline: Amazon Is Said to Plan to Lay Off Thousands of Employees
articles.snippet: The job cuts of approximately 10,000, which would start as soon as this week, would focus on the company’s devices organization, retail division and human resources.
articles.abstract: The job cuts of approximately 10,000, which would start as soon as this week, would focus on the company’s devices organization, retail division and human resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon plans to lay off approximately 10,000 people in corporate and technology jobs starting as soon as this week, people with knowledge of the matter said, in what would be the largest job cuts in the company’s history.
